node.title: Met Museum to Renovate Its Ancient Near East and Cypriot Galleries
node.alt: A rendering of a renovation at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. It will merge collections from the Eastern Mediterranean coast and West Asia, reinforcing their cross-cultural connections.
node.description: Construction for the $40 million project is expected to start next year and finish in 2025.
node.content: ["The Metropolitan Museum of Art is planning a $40 million initiative to renovate its Ancient Near East and Cypriot galleries, museum officials announced on Tuesday. The collection holds some of the institution\u2019s most recognizable ancient works from the Eastern Mediterranean coast extending through Iran, including a pair of towering lamassu sculptures \u2014 winged lions with human heads \u2014 from the ninth century B.C.", "Nader Tehrani, principal of the architecture firm NADAAA, has designed the new space, using elements that reflect the materials of the exhibited artworks, such as the deep blues of lapis lazuli seen in Sumerian designs. Kim Benzel and Se\u00e1n Hemingway, curators at the museum, will oversee the project. They aim to integrate these separate areas of the collection into an updated display that demonstrates the cross-cultural connections between the Near East \u2014 now commonly referred to as West Asia \u2014 and Cyprus.", "\u201cThe Met has a strong commitment to updating our narratives,\u201d Max Hollein, the museum\u2019s director, said in an interview. He said that new scholarship would influence the curatorial direction of the galleries, which have not been renovated since 1999.", "Hollein said that fund-raising for the 15,000-square-foot project is about halfway complete. Construction is to begin later this year, and museum officials expect the galleries to reopen in 2025.", "The museum is undergoing several other major renovations, which include changes to the Michael C. Rockefeller Wing, as well as projects in its European paintings section and its galleries for modern and contemporary art."]
